requirements.txt.message:
(sorry going off on a tangent here but... ) so this is done with pip freeze right? 

I have a general question. So I understand this makes pip job much easier (and so yours too) in resolving and installing stuffs and our jobs are faster etc. 

But what is the plan for this file how do we keep it from going very stale? Something like, periodically, run your tests, rerun pip freeze and update the requirements file?

That is pinning the deps only for testing. While this is not published we could also do the pinning on requirements.

This repo may confuse people because is not shipping any python code.

That is not output of `pip freeze` but very similar. pip freeze report ALL installed stuff from a particular venv, pip-compile builds a freeze list for a package (smaller list).

No need to run periodic on these, when we want we will update them by running "tox -e deps" and uploading the change. Believe me that this will translate to less work for us (we do it only when we want/need, and avoid surprises like sudden suprises).

tox.ini.message: ah i guess this is what generates the requirements.txt
YES. That is the magic line, and FYI you can also use setup.cfg as input, not only the requirements.in, very useful for packages.

etc/neutron/keepalived.conf.j2.message: This template file is not changable in real deployment. Because you add or remove any {{variable}} here may directly cause the L3 agent failed to render the final keepalvied config file. So everytime you change this, you need to change the code as well. So the inline jinja2 template should be fine to this refactor work.

More things in real deployment are that if users upgrade the code which is trying to render the keepalived with {{new variable}}, but the etc/neutron/keepalived.conf.j2 in their host may not get changed at all. Then there may be nothing changed for final keepalvied config file.

doc/source/reference/developer/specs/com.message: Aw shoot.  I'll fix it in a followup so we don't lose all the votes.
Matrix provides a simple lightweight HTTP API relatively easy to use for bots: https://matrix.org/docs/spec/client_server/latest

Note that this is possible to accomplish with DCC in IRC as well if clients have interoperable implementations (e.g. OTR), though is not straightforward to configure and get working. But for any of these sorts of solutions the key distribution problem is the most challenging part, I haven't looked at Matrix's E2E encryption to see how they ease that.

I think I meant either -- I was trying to point out that one possible alternative is for some/most of us to do what I'm doing right now, which is just IRC through matrix, but that goes from a single point of failure to a double point of failure system.

If I switch to "neither", that suggests that neither system is capable of an outage, and I bet they both are.
Oh, yep you're right. I originally misread the sentence. Thanks.
That would be my strong recommendation.
With what little I know about it so far, I would still consider the OpenDev SSO spec a prerequisite for hosting any user accounts on the hypothetical homeserver.
Good question, and I don't have the answer at hand.

I suppose we could cover this in the OpenDev spec, but I'm curious what the high availability options are for homeservering... like if one homeserver is down can a replica of the channel continue on a different homeserver?

Something else I wouldn't mind seeing in the OpenDev spec... what are the potential integration points/options for our existing Jitst-Meet+Etherpad deployment? Does having our own homeserver in OpenDev open up more possibilities there?

doc/source/reference/developer/specs/ten.message:
I *think* that the intent is for the tenant-resources limit to be global across all providers, but it would be good to specify that.  The reason I think that is that you cited the use case of a number of openstack clouds, and, if we use the opendev system as an example, it doesn't make a lot of sense to me to have tenant quotas for each provider in the general case.

However, it does make sense to me that we might want to give, say, airship extended use of special nodes.  We can already limit labels to tenants, so we can set up an all-or-none control.  But is there a use case for saying "this tenant can have 200 cores from this provider, and another tenant can have 400 cores from the same provider"?

That sounds complicated to describe and I sure don't want to set up a system that way.  So maybe if we don't have an immediate use case for that, we should just implement this as a global limit.  And if it comes up later, I think we could add it in as a provider-level config.

-1: Assuming this all sounds good, let's state somewhere in here explicitly that the tenant-resources limit is global across all providers.

When I was trying to determine whether this made sense as a global or per-provider config, I considered that right now the launchers effectively only handle nodes from their own providers.  In other words, the QuotaSupport class only looks at nodes from that provider.

However, it does *read* all of the nodes from ZK, so the additionaly load of calculating a global quota won't be significant.  So that's fine.

However (again), it establishes quota usage by calling quotaNeededByLabel, which can have side effects of calling provider methods.  That could mean one provider calling another provider's methods, and that won't work (it won't have started).  So we should fully adopt the method of putting the resource usage information in the ZK Node entries.  We should make sure all providers do that in all cases, and then remove the quotaNeededByLabel call in the QuotaSupport class, so it (and the new method) will rely only on data in ZK.

There's already a zk.Node.resources dictionary, which the OpenStack driver fills in with a dictionary with keys 'cores', 'instances', 'ram'.  I think we shound standardize all drivers to use that.

I would suggest you either make this more vague ("Add resource information to zk.Node in a standardized way in all drivers") or update it to say "Standardize all drivers to supply a resources dictionary to zk.Node with keys: cores, instances, ram (as the OpenStack driver currently does)").

That will improve Zuul's resource reporting as a side effect since it already reads that.

Well, that's about to stop being true for Azure at least, and should be easy to rectify for AWS.  That's why we standardizing on using the Node.resources dictionary.

I might rephrase this to just say that since the AWS and Azure drivers currently (as of this writing) have incomplete quota support, the tenant limits will only be as good as the driver support for quota.
Okay this sentence "global limits as intended for tenant quotas" seems to address my comment on line 96 of ps 2.

Good point; I was assuming it would be like min-ready, which is sort of "caveat operator".  The values would be used independently by each launcher.  I don't think this has the same race condition properties of min-ready that lead us to pick a "primary" launcher.  Instead, they should be kept the same on all of the launchers.  Technically they could be different though.  If they are different, I don't think it would cause a problem, just be confusing why some launchers could apparently exceed the capacity while others never get to launch anything.

I think in the long run we might want to move to a single global state in ZK, but we need to work out the lifecycle for that.  I think the idea that they should be the same everywhere is workable enough (and matches the current design) that it doesn't need to be a pre-requisite for this.

It might be worth writing down how this global config should be handled in a distributed system. Currently OpenDev runs 4 nodepool launchers and 3 builders. Each of the launchers runs a different config. Would we be required to pick a primary launcher and define the limits there? Or would we need to set the same limits across the board? Maybe nodepool would take the most conservative config?

I think we have options here. I think it would be good to think about what we want to have though.

It will effectively be a high priority since it's the head of the queue at this point; the next launcher to look at the queue (which could be this one), will see it first (or at least, after all the other similar requests it skipped).
We might want to prioritize requests which were previously passed over due to tenant limits to avoid starving tenants when near our global resource limits.
Could we do a simple max-servers limit for kubernetes and other drivers?
We could -- I feel like there are equally legitimate use cases for counting a k8s pod as a "server" and not doing so.  Either way, we pick a side.

doc/source/reference/developer/specs/enh.message:
It's a little ambiguous, but I think "source zone" means "the zone provided with the request".  However, what about the case of an unzoned zuul-web making a request?  In that case, the scheduler should provide the zoned fingergw address.

I think these rules should be:
   * Address of executor if the zone provided with the request matches the zone of the executor running the build, or the executor is un-zoned.
   * Address of fingergw in the target zone otherwise.
Perhaps we should go ahead and use the ZK component registry for this?
Yes, of course, that now makes much more sense since that now exists.

In the proposed change, we are adding zone information to zuul-web and zuul-fingergw, and I believe that is to support the idea that some or all of these services might be geographically distributed.  In other words (just focusing on zuul-web here): an operator may deploy a Zuul with 2 zuul-web processes, each of which is in an executor zone, and load balance between them.  These processes need to know their own zones so that they can make appropriate requests to fingergw services for log forwarding, however, they will be indistinguishable from each other for end users.  A user could connect to either one and will be able to access logs from anywhere.

It *almost* goes without saying since I believe universal accessibility is really the point of this spec, but it's still probably worth being clear that end users will never need to see or know anything about executor zoning, and that zuul-web and zuul-fingergw will still have a single canonical URL for end users to use and type into their address bars or terminals.  Maybe something like:

While zuul-web and zuul-fingergw will be aware of what zone they are running in, end-users will not need this information; the user-facing instances of those services will continue to serve the entirely of the Zuul system regardless of which zone they reside in, all from a single public URL or address.
Yes, you're right that in the end universal accessibility is the point of this spec. I'll add your proposed clarification.
nit: the change is already merged.
I think that method to supply a CA file and only accept connections from certs signed by that CA, right?  If so, I agree.
Yes, essentially the same we do with gearman.

Currently we don't have many issues with executors behind NAT because they connect to the rest of the cluster rather than having connections made to them. The proposal presented here should work just fine, but I wonder if we would be better off with having the zoned executors connect out to the finger gateways creating a connection that is happy behind NAT. Then when the fingergw looks up a stream location it can simply request it from the connection that already exists for that executor?

Where this gets complicated is we'll need to be able to run multiple streams over that single connection so tcp alone is probably insufficient?

Mostly thinking out loud here to point out the existing NAT bypass methodology to see if that might be preferred if workable.

That sounds workable; it could use a multiplexing protocol, or the persistent connection could be used just to tell the executor to establish another connection to start a stream.

That's probably easier for the NAT case, but it's probably a coin toss for the k8s case (either way, you add a new nodeport service; just on the remote cluster in the first case, and the main cluster in the second).

Given the marginal benefit plus additional complexity, I'm inclined to say let's stick with this and if the NAT issue is bothersome enough for someone to want to implement the callback idea in the future, great.

nodepool/driver/azurestate/adapter.py.message:
A central premise of the nodepool launcher design is that we intentionally want to serialize API calls to a particular cloud; they should be much shorter than the actual work of launching nodes.  We have done quite a lot of work in the existing openstack driver (much of which is now in openstacksdk) to ensure this.  That's what the whole "taskmanager" thing is about.  A given provider-pool makes a single API call at a time.  The taskmanager has a thread that actually executes those calls; the rest of the threads are simply to keep track of the state of the individual instance launches.

A big part of the idea here is to keep that behavior, but eliminate the overhead of context switching between threads.

I'm not sure that we should try to paralellize more than we already are.  It makes rate limiting difficult to calculate, and even with all the limitations we have, Nodepool has caused at least two full-scale service outages on public OpenStack clouds (these are at least the ones we know about).

(Also, depending on exactly what openstack is doing in those api requests, there's a really good chance than parelellizing won't actually make it better.  Might make it worse.  Certainly worth looking into.)

Since this runs synchronously I wonder what's the expected runtime of those api calls. I know that quite some api calls on our openstack clouds are in the order of seconds which is likely too slow to have it inside the critical path in the state machine.

So I think in order to really gain speed here in future we likely will need to move all remote api calls to the threadpool like the key scanning. I think a shared threadpool for all those actions might make sense.

I think this would mimick the asyncio approach quite closely without giving up threads.

We could move it into the base class and then override it, but i didn't want to have any assumptions about a thread in the base class (but we could add a comment to remind us that some providers override it).  We could make a thin subclass with just this method.  But we have a lot of duplication in the providers anyway.  I guess they're all options.  :)

nodepool/driver/statemachine.py.message: It is an issue, but happily we can address it without going full-on asyncio.  This is moved to a threadpool and future model in https://review.opendev.org/779379 (about 2 or 3 changes down the stack from here).

Could you extend the code comment a bit based on what we discussed in the review?

same compute nodes and vms as describe before.

Now nova-compute service in node01 and node02 is stopped. We need to evacuate these 2 vms.

Now vm01 is doing later check at first and do not see any other servers are being migrated to the same host. vm01 has finished evacuation. When vm02 is doing later check, it found no other servers are being migrated to the same host but target host has one server. So vm02 fails to evacuate.

How this test case now ensures that the two evacuation happens in parallel?

As there is a third situation. One of the evacuation finished before the second is scheduled and therefore the second scheduling stops before the race can even reproduced. If this happens then this test case does not reproduce the original problem.

Yeah, you're right. The B2 is not the goal for our testcase.
But now I have no good idea to seperate or control only to trigger B1. Any idea? thanks.

> How this test case now ensures that the two evacuation happens in
 > parallel?

We just insure that we call the evacuate api in parallel. But the internal logic call may exist successively. So we have two situations as described before.

 > 
 > As there is a third situation. One of the evacuation finished
 > before the second is scheduled and therefore the second scheduling
 > stops before the race can even reproduced. If this happens then
 > this test case does not reproduce the original problem.

Sorry. I don't fully understand this situation. I find it is like my second situation. :(

See my answer in the above comment about the case B situation. In that case the you need that the second scheduling happens _before_ the first evac finishes. As if the first evac finishes before the second scheduling then the second scheduling already see the first vm on the compute and wont select that compute for the second vm at all. Therefore it is not the late check of the second vm that prevent the evacuation but the scheduler. 

Your current testcase in case B allows both situation to happen:
* B1: second vm scheduling happens _before the first evacuation finishes. The late check for the second vm will be called and will fail the second evacuation.
* B2: the second scheduling happens _after_ the first vm finished evacuating therefore the scheduling of the second evacuation finds no valid host. In this case the late check does not even called for the second vm.

So each run of the current test case might trigger B1 or B2 but we don't know which one. But we want to always trigger B1 instead of B2 as only B1 calls the late check that this test case want to validate.
In the original test waiting for the notification was use to catch the proper timing. It is not used for timing here so I think you can simply drop this.

nova/virt/libvirt/guest.py.message: We're keeping nvram for swap_volume, live_snapshot and hard_reboot, right? Could explain a little how it works and why those operations?

> We're keeping nvram for swap_volume, live_snapshot and hard_reboot,
 > right? Could explain a little how it works and why those
 > operations?

We are keeping nvrams for basically any state-preserving operations: stop/start, live/cold migrations, hard-reboots.

We would also keep nvram when powering off an instance, rebooting an instance, shutting down in preparation for cold migration/resize, etc.

Basically we only want to delete the NVRAM file after the instance is no longer present on the given compute node.

specs/xena/approved/glance/cache-api.rst.message: I thought user should have permission to queue image for caching, so it should use policy used for create_image or has its own?

No, I would not think that you would want this. Cache space is limited on each node. If every user decides to cache every image, there won't be cache space for all of them.

I think the use-case for this is so that admins can pre-cache images that are commonly-used, like the default ubuntu and windows images. Also for an edge operator to make sure that images are cached on specific workers at specific sites so that they don't have to take a long download hit on the first boot.

These commands would go directly to the public endpoint and affect only one unknown worker. In a real deployment all of these in a row would hit *different* workers and be super confusing.

How does one target a specific worker? Presumably a direct URL override option on the command-line?

I wonder if it would make sense to make these commands *refuse* to run without such a direct override? Otherwise just using them as shown here is almost certainly going to confuse everyone with a larger deployment than devstack.
+1, I think I will add one more lite-spec for python-glanceclient implementation and explain it there?

It seems like saying this will have no impact is kinda misleading. I think that today admins run the local image caching commands _on_ the node that they intend to target right? Presumably with ansible or something else that knows all of the nodes and their roles, caching from a manifest of golden images. Are you expecting them to have glance client installed on those nodes, have it read glance-api.conf and connect to localhost? That would likely be a change there (having glance client installed on a worker node), but I'm guessing not. Even still, WSGI services won't have the port (or the right one) configured and you won't really be able to deduce the correct URL reliably.

If you're expecting this to be used remotely (I assume you are), operators will need to know the direct URL of each worker node from behind the load balancer, right? Will they provide that URL to the glance client as an override?
Yep, this is a valid point, I think existing glance-cache-manage use to have --host and --port options, so we should use them in glance-client as well.

We have a two-glance job for distributed-import, so we should be able to test that each returns a different set of image cache results, but we probably need to modify devstack to have them place their cache dir/db in different places. I definitely think that a tempest test should be required, since it should be quite easy to write, given the existing infrastructure we have.
Thank you for pointing this out!

This is helpful when grokking the above, since the general per-node caching model isn't covered in this spec:

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/victoria/admin/cache.html

Probably worth adding.

I think "cache_image" would be a much more logical choice.

I definitely think this _has_ to be different permissions than create_image and delete_image.

If we are going to be defining new commands in glanceclient, is there any reason not to call this cache-image? I think it makes a lot more sense than queue-image. I'm guessing the existing tool name provides the context, but in glance client itself, this won't obviously be related to caching.

FWIW, I meant to add this to the references section:

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/victoria/admin/cache.html

I guess I commented on the doc one, so that probably wasn't clear.

NIT: Either "_" or "-" specially in single paragraph ;)

Also can we be consistent with the names, maybe "cache_queue", "cache_delete" and "cache_list" just like on the client examples below rather than swapping the order around.

Listing should be under it's own policy rule to ease up the read-only roles etc.
404 Not Found in a case the image does not exists, user does not have rights to it?

Totally agree with Dan's concern in PS6 about the 'queue-image' not being obvious, maybe rather "cache-queue" than "cache-image" to avoid confusion further (the image will not be cached at the point when user gets 204 created response).

I think all of these are async and will be noted in the docs right? AIUI, a subsequent cache-list will show that the image is queued until it's cached right? I think that covers us. IMHO "cache-queue" doesn't immediately scream "this will cache an image" to me, but it's definitely better than "queue-image" :)
Ack, we will finalize the name in glanceclient lite spec.

I think there is a whole lot more change implied by these few words than some of us realized. The only piece of code proposed for this just adds a few more APIs to the existing stuff to flesh out the capabilities. It sounds like this is actually converting an api-in-middleware to a proper API (i.e. moving that modified section of code to an API instead of a piece of middleware).

It would probably be good to call that out more explicitly here.
I suggest naming these cache_image, cache_list, and cache_delete.

As noted in the IRC meeting just now, it would be good if we can have some better definition of the policy aspects here, specifically about how we can make this secure-rbac-compliant from the start. Moving it to a proper API where we look up the image in question, etc will be an important part of that.
I think weshould also remove documentation regarding glance-cache-manage and glance-cache-prefetcher, shouldn't we?

hooks/glance_contexts.py.message: I think we'll want an else path here to log an error if one of the options is not set but the others are set.

I believe the convention is generally that you should just change - to _ for keys in the context dict as translating from config options. This is patterned in reactive charms via the charms.openstack framework, but may not be completely followed in some of the older classic style charms (which glance is) due to legacy cruft. As such, s3-store-host config option would become s3_store_host, etc.
I think the keys in the above 2 need the variable name rearranged to match S3ObjectStoreContext.
We could also decide to block the unit here? I think operators would like to know about this misconfiguration and not miss it.
